Label: .5 sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential - Larry H. Brace (NASA/GSFC)

VariableDescription.Name: OrbitNumber
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 LANG 0.5-sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      plasma500ms> plasma 500 msec
#     DATA_TYPE                       LANG> Langmuir Probe Instrument
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Langmuir Probe Instrument (LANG) was a cylindrical electrostatic probe that                        
#     TEXT                             obtained measurements of electron temperature, Te, and electron or ion concentration,                 
#     TEXT                             Ne or Ni, respectively, and spacecraft potential.  Data from this investigation                       
#     TEXT                             were used to provide temperature and density measurements along magnetic field                        
#     TEXT                             lines related to thermal energy and particle flows within the magnetosphere-ionosphere                
#     TEXT                             system, to provide thermal plasma conditions for wave-particle interactions,                          
#     TEXT                             and to measure large-scale and fine-structure ionospheric effects of energy                           
#     TEXT                             deposition in the ionosphere.  The Langmuir Probe instrument was identical                            
#     TEXT                             to that used on the AE satellites and the Pioneer Venus Orbiter. Two independent                      
#     TEXT                             sensors were connected to individual adaptive sweep voltage circuits which                            
#     TEXT                             continuously tracked the changing electron temperature and spacecraft potential,                      
#     TEXT                             while autoranging electrometers adjusted their gain in response to the changing                       
#     TEXT                             plasma density. The control signals used to achieve this automatic tracking                           
#     TEXT                             provided a continuous monitor of the ionospheric parameters without telemetering                      
#     TEXT                             each volt-ampere (V-I) curve.  Furthermore, internal data storage circuits                            
#     TEXT                             permitted high resolution, high data rate sampling of selected V-I curves for                         
#     TEXT                             transmission to ground to verify or correct the inflight processed data. Time                         
#     TEXT                             resolution was 0.5 seconds. More details are in J. P. Krehbiel et al., Space                          
#                                      Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 493, 1981.                                                              
#                                     The Dynamics Explorer 2 Langmuir Probe (LANG) ASCII files contain the following                        
#                                      geophysical parameters: electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite                           
#                                      potential.  They also contain the most important DE-2 orbit parameters.  The                          
#                                      geophysical parameters in the ASCII files were derived.from the raw volt-ampere                       
#                                      data from LANG.  PI-provided software was used to convert the raw binary data                         
#                                      into the ASCII geophysical data.                                                                      
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_plasma500ms_lang
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_plasma500ms_lang_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      .5 sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential
#     PI_NAME                         Larry H. Brace
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  NASA/GSFC
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00137
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. Orbit Number
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:45:37 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Orbit Number
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.       ORBIT_NUMBER
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms              
05-08-1981 20:31:02.480           36

VariableDescription.Name: electronTemp
VariableDescription.Header:

#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******

#     DESCRIPTOR                      plasma500ms> plasma 500 msec
#     DATA_TYPE                       LANG> Langmuir Probe Instrument
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Langmuir Probe Instrument (LANG) was a cylindrical electrostatic probe that                        
#     TEXT                             obtained measurements of electron temperature, Te, and electron or ion concentration,                 
#     TEXT                             Ne or Ni, respectively, and spacecraft potential.  Data from this investigation                       
#     TEXT                             were used to provide temperature and density measurements along magnetic field                        
#     TEXT                             lines related to thermal energy and particle flows within the magnetosphere-ionosphere                
#     TEXT                             system, to provide thermal plasma conditions for wave-particle interactions,                          
#     TEXT                             and to measure large-scale and fine-structure ionospheric effects of energy                           
#     TEXT                             deposition in the ionosphere.  The Langmuir Probe instrument was identical                            
#     TEXT                             to that used on the AE satellites and the Pioneer Venus Orbiter. Two independent                      
#     TEXT                             sensors were connected to individual adaptive sweep voltage circuits which                            
#     TEXT                             continuously tracked the changing electron temperature and spacecraft potential,                      
#     TEXT                             while autoranging electrometers adjusted their gain in response to the changing                       
#     TEXT                             plasma density. The control signals used to achieve this automatic tracking                           
#     TEXT                             provided a continuous monitor of the ionospheric parameters without telemetering                      
#     TEXT                             each volt-ampere (V-I) curve.  Furthermore, internal data storage circuits                            
#     TEXT                             permitted high resolution, high data rate sampling of selected V-I curves for                         
#     TEXT                             transmission to ground to verify or correct the inflight processed data. Time                         
#     TEXT                             resolution was 0.5 seconds. More details are in J. P. Krehbiel et al., Space                          
#                                      Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 493, 1981.                                                              
#                                     The Dynamics Explorer 2 Langmuir Probe (LANG) ASCII files contain the following                        
#                                      geophysical parameters: electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite                           
#                                      potential.  They also contain the most important DE-2 orbit parameters.  The                          
#                                      geophysical parameters in the ASCII files were derived.from the raw volt-ampere                       
#                                      data from LANG.  PI-provided software was used to convert the raw binary data                         
#                                      into the ASCII geophysical data.                                                                      
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_plasma500ms_lang
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_plasma500ms_lang_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      .5 sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential
#     PI_NAME                         Larry H. Brace
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  NASA/GSFC
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00137

#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based

#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. Electron temperature in Kelvin
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:45:37 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Electron temperature in Kelvin
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.                  TE
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms              K
05-08-1981 20:31:02.480       4649.00

#     TEXT                            The Langmuir Probe Instrument (LANG) was a cylindrical electrostatic probe that                        
#     TEXT                             obtained measurements of electron temperature, Te, and electron or ion concentration,                 
#     TEXT                             Ne or Ni, respectively, and spacecraft potential.  Data from this investigation                       
#     TEXT                             were used to provide temperature and density measurements along magnetic field

#     TEXT                             system, to provide thermal plasma conditions for wave-particle interactions,                          
#     TEXT                             and to measure large-scale and fine-structure ionospheric effects of energy                           
#     TEXT                             deposition in the ionosphere.  The Langmuir Probe instrument was identical                            
#     TEXT                             to that used on the AE satellites and the Pioneer Venus Orbiter. Two independent                      
#     TEXT                             sensors were connected to individual adaptive sweep voltage circuits which                            
#     TEXT                             continuously tracked the changing electron temperature and spacecraft potential,                      
#     TEXT                             while autoranging electrometers adjusted their gain in response to the changing

#     TEXT                             obtained measurements of electron temperature, Te, and electron or ion concentration,                 
#     TEXT                             Ne or Ni, respectively, and spacecraft potential.  Data from this investigation                       
#     TEXT                             were used to provide temperature and density measurements along magnetic field

#     TEXT                             system, to provide thermal plasma conditions for wave-particle interactions,                          
#     TEXT                             and to measure large-scale and fine-structure ionospheric effects of energy                           
#     TEXT                             deposition in the ionosphere.  The Langmuir Probe instrument was identical                            
#     TEXT                             to that used on the AE satellites and the Pioneer Venus Orbiter. Two independent                      
#     TEXT                             sensors were connected to individual adaptive sweep voltage circuits which                            
#     TEXT                             continuously tracked the changing electron temperature and spacecraft potential,                      
#     TEXT                             while autoranging electrometers adjusted their gain in response to the changing                       
#     TEXT                             plasma density. The control signals used to achieve this automatic tracking                           
#     TEXT                             provided a continuous monitor of the ionospheric parameters without telemetering

#     TEXT                             plasma density. The control signals used to achieve this automatic tracking                           
#     TEXT                             provided a continuous monitor of the ionospheric parameters without telemetering                      
#     TEXT                             each volt-ampere (V-I) curve.  Furthermore, internal data storage circuits                            
#     TEXT                             permitted high resolution, high data rate sampling of selected V-I curves for                         
#     TEXT                             transmission to ground to verify or correct the inflight processed data. Time                         
#     TEXT                             resolution was 0.5 seconds. More details are in J. P. Krehbiel et al., Space                          
#                                      Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 493, 1981.                                                              
#                                     The Dynamics Explorer 2 Langmuir Probe (LANG) ASCII files contain the following                        
#                                      geophysical parameters: electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite                           
#                                      potential.  They also contain the most important DE-2 orbit parameters.  The                          
#                                      geophysical parameters in the ASCII files were derived.from the raw volt-ampere                       
#                                      data from LANG.  PI-provided software was used to convert the raw binary data                         
#                                      into the ASCII geophysical data.

VariableDescription.Name: lmt
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 LANG 0.5-sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      plasma500ms> plasma 500 msec
#     DATA_TYPE                       LANG> Langmuir Probe Instrument
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Langmuir Probe Instrument (LANG) was a cylindrical electrostatic probe that                        
#     TEXT                             obtained measurements of electron temperature, Te, and electron or ion concentration,                 
#     TEXT                             Ne or Ni, respectively, and spacecraft potential.  Data from this investigation                       
#     TEXT                             were used to provide temperature and density measurements along magnetic field                        
#     TEXT                             lines related to thermal energy and particle flows within the magnetosphere-ionosphere                
#     TEXT                             system, to provide thermal plasma conditions for wave-particle interactions,                          
#     TEXT                             and to measure large-scale and fine-structure ionospheric effects of energy                           
#     TEXT                             deposition in the ionosphere.  The Langmuir Probe instrument was identical                            
#     TEXT                             to that used on the AE satellites and the Pioneer Venus Orbiter. Two independent                      
#     TEXT                             sensors were connected to individual adaptive sweep voltage circuits which                            
#     TEXT                             continuously tracked the changing electron temperature and spacecraft potential,                      
#     TEXT                             while autoranging electrometers adjusted their gain in response to the changing                       
#     TEXT                             plasma density. The control signals used to achieve this automatic tracking                           
#     TEXT                             provided a continuous monitor of the ionospheric parameters without telemetering                      
#     TEXT                             each volt-ampere (V-I) curve.  Furthermore, internal data storage circuits                            
#     TEXT                             permitted high resolution, high data rate sampling of selected V-I curves for                         
#     TEXT                             transmission to ground to verify or correct the inflight processed data. Time                         
#     TEXT                             resolution was 0.5 seconds. More details are in J. P. Krehbiel et al., Space                          
#                                      Sci. Instrum., v. 5, n. 4, p. 493, 1981.                                                              
#                                     The Dynamics Explorer 2 Langmuir Probe (LANG) ASCII files contain the following                        
#                                      geophysical parameters: electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite                           
#                                      potential.  They also contain the most important DE-2 orbit parameters.  The                          
#                                      geophysical parameters in the ASCII files were derived.from the raw volt-ampere                       
#                                      data from LANG.  PI-provided software was used to convert the raw binary data                         
#                                      into the ASCII geophysical data.                                                                      
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_plasma500ms_lang
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_plasma500ms_lang_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      .5 sec electron temperature, plasma density, and satellite potential
#     PI_NAME                         Larry H. Brace
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  NASA/GSFC
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00137
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. Local Magnetic Time (LMT) in hours
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:45:40 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Local Magnetic Time (LMT) in hours
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.                 LMT
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms             hr
05-08-1981 20:31:02.480       3.28000
